clinical_study.brief_title: Prospective Evaluation of Frenotomies of Labial and Lingual Frena for Management of Breastfeeding Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Frenotomy of Newborns With Ankyloglossia or Maxillary Lip-tie and Effects on Breastfeeding: 2 Randomized, Prospective Studies.

brief_summary.textblock:
The study is comprised of two randomized control studies, one of which aims to contribute data to a previous study on the effects of ankyloglossia (tongue-tie) on breastfeeding, and the other aims to provide new information on the effects of maxillary lip-tie on breastfeeding. Participants who are determined eligible for the ankyloglossia study will be randomly assigned to either Group AnkA or Group AnkB. Group AnkA will receive a frenotomy procedure for intervention #1 and a sham procedure for intervention #2. Group AnkB will receive a sham procedure for intervention #1 and a frenotomy procedure for intervention #2. Mothers will be kept blinded and then asked to complete pain scale and LATCH surveys before and after intervention #1. Then, intervention #2 will take place, and then the mother will breastfeed again and complete the same surveys again. In addition to studying ankyloglossia, infants presenting with Class III and IV maxillary frena will be screened for and studied for their effect on breastfeeding in a separate study (maxillary lip-tie study) using similar techniques.
Both these studies aim to prove that the simple and low risk frenotomy procedure should be considered as treatment for both ankyloglossia and maxillary lip-tie, preventing breastfeeding complications as well as many other future problems such as with speech and self esteem. It is expected to see an increase in LATCH score to >7 for breastfeeding sessions and a significant decrease in scoring on the pain scale after frenotomy intervention, while it is expected to see little change in LATCH and pain scale assessment scores after sham procedures. Overall data is not expected to vary significantly between Group AnkA and Group AnkB or between Group Max A and Group Max B.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Crossover Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Caregiver, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Wong-Baker FACES Pain Rating Scale Before and After Intervention #1 and Intervention #2
primary_outcome.time_frame: after breastfeeding before intervention #1, after breastfeeding after intervention #1, after breastfeeding after intervention #2, and during 2 week follow-up
primary_outcome.description: This visual pain analog scale is used to measure breastfeeding pain experienced by the mother.

arm_group.description: All participants will receive both the lingual frenotomy and the sham procedure. For Ankyloglossia A (AnkA) group, infants will receive lingual frenotomy for intervention #1 and then a sham procedure for intervention #2. When receiving the lingual frenotomy, the tongue of the infants will be elevated and the frenulum exposed with a grooved director or 2 cotton tipped applicators. The frenulum tissue will then be incised with a straight scissor. When receiving the sham/placebo procedure, they will be brought into a procedure room and kept there for as long as the average experimental procedure would take (~5 minutes).

All participating infants will receive both the lingual frenotomy as well as the sham procedure. For the Ankyloglossia B (AnkB) group, infants will receive the sham procedure for intervention #1 and then a lingual frenotomy for intervention #2. When receiving the sham/placebo procedure, they will be brought into a procedure room and kept there for as long as the average experimental procedure would take (~5 minutes). When receiving the lingual frenotomy, the tongue of the infants will be elevated and the frenulum exposed with a grooved director or 2 cotton tipped applicators. The frenulum tissue will then be incised with a straight scissor.

All participating infants will receive both the labial frenotomy as well as the sham procedure. For the Maxillary Lip-Tie A (MaxA) group, infants will receive the labial frenotomy for intervention #1 and then a sham procedure for intervention #2. When receiving the maxillary labial frenotomy, the newborn's upper lip will be lifted and the frenum stretched. Then a Xlase 1064 nm laser will be used to release its attachment to the level of the periosteum. When receiving the sham/placebo procedure, the newborn will be brought into a procedure room and kept there for as long as the average experimental procedure would take (~5 minutes).

All participating infants will receive both the labial frenotomy as well as the sham procedure. For the Maxillary Lip-Tie B (MaxB) group, infants will receive the sham procedure for intervention #1 and then a labial frenotomy for intervention #2. When receiving the maxillary labial frenotomy, the newborn's upper lip will be lifted and the frenum stretched. Then a Xlase 1064 nm laser will be used to release its attachment to the level of the periosteum. When receiving the sham/placebo procedure, the newborn will be brought into a procedure room and kept there for as long as the average experimental procedure would take (~5 minutes).

intervention.description: 2 cotton tipped applicators placed to lift the tongue. THen the frenum is snipped with straight scissors.
Safety goggles placed. Upper lip is lifted. The labial frenum is incised using Xlase laser.
Baby taken to exam room and kept there for 5 minutes, no procedures are performed.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ankyloglossia Study Inclusion Criteria:
1. Infant is full term (at least 37 weeks) and otherwise in good health.
2. Patient exhibits having ankyloglossia (score of less than 4 with failing lactation management or an appearance score lower than 8, based on HATLFF).
3. Mother of infant noted to have nipple pain or difficulty with breastfeeding.
4. Mother of infant signs a written informed consent for treatment.
- Maxillary Lip-Tie Study Inclusion Criteria:
1. Infant is full term (at least 37 weeks) and otherwise in good health.
2. Patient exhibits having a Class III or Class IV maxillary lip-tie.
3. Mother of infant noted to have nipple pain or difficulty with breastfeeding.
4. Mother of infant signs a written informed consent for treatment.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Ankyloglossia Study Exclusion Criteria:
1. Premature infants.
2. Infants older than 2 weeks.
3. Infants with craniofacial anomalies (i.e. cleft lip or palate).
4. Infants who are neurologically compromised.
5. Infants with Class III or Class IV maxillary labial frenum.
6. Mother of infant is not English speaking and not able to read at least at a 6th grade level.
- Maxillary Lip-Tie Study Exclusion Criteria:
1. Premature infants.
2. Infants older than 2 weeks.
3. Infants with craniofacial anomalies (i.e. cleft lip or palate)
4. Infants who are neurologically compromised.
5. Infants with ankyloglossia.
6. Mother of infant is not English speaking and not able to read at least at a 6th grade level.
